content.description: On the left side of the north face of the Amphitheatre. This problem starts at a sidepull hold and foot smear. Launch up and catch a small crimp high on the wall. Walk your feet and bump up about six inches to another small crimp. Now walk your feet up like crazy until your left foot is on the lower of the two crimps, and you should be able to reach the top! Cool movement.

In the San Diego Climbing Guide(2006) this route is listed as route #1267. "Thin face."

Beginning and ending right of "the obvious 5.7 Â down climb shelf located approximately one foot from the top.

A few start options including a deadpoint hop up to a crimp or cranking on a half-pad mono (yipes!).  Crank up past the crimp into the "V" shaped flake and top out.  Only a few moves on this one, but they're hard!
content.location: 10 feet right of "Walkman" on the North side of the Amphitheater boulder.

content.description:
Kind of a contrived line but adds an extra cool move to One Cut Above. Same starting moves as for One Cut Above. About 10 feet up, match the right hand "triangle hold." Then desperately bust out around the corner to the right to a chunky sidepull. Pull around the corner to match then easy top out.

*As with everything in Santee, this has likely been climbed before. Please let me know in the comments and I'll change any relevant information.
content.protection: Pad or two would be preferable.

content.description: This problem ascends the overhanging face right of the southeast arete of the Amphitheatre boulder, using the arete. Start left hand on arete, right hand on a low sidepull crimp. Using your choice of sequence, bump your left hand up the arete to a good hold about 8 feet up, walk your feet up on small edges, and pop your right hand to the triangle shaped incut sidepull above. Once you establish on these two handholds, the crux is over. Continue up and eventually go left around the arete onto the slabby south face and top out.
content.protection: Pad is useful due to uneven landing
content.location: the right side of the SE arete of the Amphitheatre boulder.

content.description: Start seated on two opposing edges and work your way up the blunt arete to join jumpstart.

One of the best problems at Santee! This one climbs the left side of the sloping southwest arete of the Amphitheatre. Start with a high foot, and walk your hands up the sloping edge. With the use of some small feet and a bad lefthand crimp, continue up the arete until you can palm all the way over the top, and top out direct, up and left. It's way easier (V1ish) you pull around right onto the slab at any point instead of continuing up the arete.

In the San Diego Climbing Guide(2006) this route is listed as route #1266. "Face."

Beginning just right of "Amp Incline (First possible route avoiding the left arete)," and ending left of the obvious 5.7 down climb shelf approximately a foot from the top.
This is a fun problem to start your day. The middle part of this problem is tougher than it looks so don't let your eyes fool you.
content.location: On the Eastside of the amphitheater. Start on the left side where the first two holds are and make your way right while staying halfway up on the boulder. Once you get all the way to the right side, then work your way up to the top. Fun little warmup!

content.description: This problem is a little more difficult than Eastside Traverse (Right). Great problem!
content.location: On the Eastside of the amphitheater. Start on the right side where the first two holds are (about chest high or so) and make your way left while staying halfway up on the boulder. Once you get all the way to the left side where the Eastside Traverse (Right) starts, then work your way up to the top

content.description:
This route is often used as the downclimb for the south face of Amphitheater. Its the simplest line on the face and it climbs up and through a large shelf a foot or so from the top.

This is not the original name of the route (if there is a name), I couldn't find any history on it.Ill leave it to the Admins if they want to update it to the historical name.
content.location: Middle left of the South Face of Amphitheater.

content.description: On the slabby south face of the Amphitheatre, start all the way left at the southwest arete. Climb up to about mid-height, and traverse right all the way across to the southeast arete, then top out. This is a great exercise in technical edging. There is also a low traverse, which is harder.
A great warm-up route on the Amphitheater, it has many crimp holds.  The print-out Santee Boulders guide lists this as a 5.8
content.location: Just to the right of Jump Start on the south face of the Amphitheater.
